Welcome to Behind the ticker.
Today we have on James St. Auburn.
He's from Ocean Park asset management where they do a number of things whether it's their

Today we're here to talk about DuckQDUKQ, which is their domestic equities ETF, focusing
at the conversation really on the signaling process, how the ETF operates and where it fits

So without further ado, please welcome Mr. James St. Auburn.
Hey James, welcome to the show.
Hi Brad, thanks for having me.
Sure.
Before we get started, always like to ask, can you give everybody a little bit about your background
and how you eventually ended up over at Ocean Park?
Sure.
Chief Investment Officer at Ocean Park, I've been here for two years and prior to that,
my career has spanned a number of firms that really all focused, all the roles that I've
had focused on, manager search, selection, so a gatekeeper role as well as asset allocation
and portfolio construction.
So I started at Smith Barney in the early days of my career and moved into consulting with

So I spent time mostly doing asset allocation, constructing target risk, target date,
portfolios for financial intermediaries.
And then more recently, I was at a head of investment strategy for a private bank and
sort of my career evolved to Ocean Park a couple of years ago and I'm very excited to be
here.
We've got a lot of exciting things going on.
Yeah, and I'm excited to talk about those things.
Before we do that, though, I always like to ask, what any hobbies you got when you're
not kind of sitting down the desk or when you're not work and what do you like to do when
you got some free time?
Yeah, free time is limited for me.
I have four kids that are between five and twelve.
So you can imagine what that means.
I've spent a lot of time in the car.
So in front of a computer screen or a shuffling, kids around to different activities.
But I like to be outdoors and that's where I'll hear a basic Santa Monica and Southern California.
They're big reason why people move out here is to be in the outdoors.
Yeah, no.
I spend a little bit of time out there as well.
It's beautiful out there.
Yeah, you're with four kids between those ages.
It's entering false sports season.
So I can assume you're all over the place.
Always on the move.
Always on the move.
So let's talk about Ocean Park as a whole.
You have a suite of ETFs, but you also do a number of other things.
You can just kind of talk about how the firm helps clients holistically and all the different
things that you do.
Sure.
So Ocean Parks, it's roots go back more than 35 years to the mid-80s.
Where the founders, I think the origin story is really interesting, where folks that
were not in finance or investing, they can't have an unconventional path to the asset management
world.
But they started in RIA, and when they started in RIA back in the mid-80s, they asked clients,
what are your concerns?
What it means most to you in your investing journey.
And they heard very much similar things and keep in mind they were targeting retirees or
folks that were near retirement.
And they all had a major concern of losing money in that very vulnerable period before
or during retirement when distributions are near and recognize the sort of psychological
impact and the sort of financial impact large declines and the market can have.
And so they developed their own proprietary strategy, which I'm sure we'll get into that
really focused on protecting the downside.
Well, hopefully, being able to participate in the upside as well, to deliver total return,
but really focused on trying to mitigate exposure to the left-tail risk that is not common,
but can be painful when it happens.
So today we have our four ETFs.
We also advise eight mutual funds under the Sierra brand, which will be changing to Ocean
Park in next month.
And we also have a solutions business, so we've been packaging our funds into as a fund
strategist and to portfolios for advisors to use of those that don't want to use their
own strategy, their own asset allocation.
They can port into a solution that combines the best of our strategies together in a way
that makes sense for a particular risk profile.
Yeah.
And we were talking before we got on like we run a very kind of similar business and also have
a very similar mindset, not only from the solution side, but the ETF, but also, you know,
we kind of have that mantra as well where it's like, you know, we'd much rather cut off as much
of the left-tail as we can, as humanly possible because that is tends to be the most painful
question and the most painful things that advisors and clients have to deal with.
So let's talk about if as much as you want as much as we can, kind of your quantitative
process and kind of that quantitative strategy holistically, you know, it seems to me it's
three parts, right?
You have security selection, which I think would that security selection would be deemed
upon, you know, what type of strategy you want to run.
And then it looks like there is, you know, a buy signal and also a sell signal.
So could you explain to me, you know, what would kind of trigger a signal on the buy side
and then, since your focus kind of more on capital preservation, you know, what that sell
signal looks like?
Is it a stop loss?
Is it technically driven, quantitatively driven, like, can you kind of get into the weeds
a little bit?
Absolutely.
So you're right, how do we start with the buy signal?
Because that's the first step.
We always say every investment manager has to answer three questions, what to buy, when
to buy, and when to sell.
So on the, when to buy question, we look for trend positive trends, right?
And signals are strategy uses banded moving averages, not to get too far into the weeds.
Here we have a lot of detail on that on our website if you're really interested.
But the banded moving averages use short-term, exponential moving averages as the bands,
and we also have another secondary, longer-term moving averages as sort of a second signal
to confirm the uptrend, and when we see that signal in a particular, like you mentioned,
we have different target markets, and we'll get into specifics later.
But whether, whatever the target market is, we'll look for funds, all of our holdings
are underlying ETFs, so we don't buy individual securities.
We're buying other underlying ETFs.
In each one of those ETFs has a band around its price, and when it crosses the recent
low of the upper band, and the secondary moving average, that is a buy signal for us.
So that's a buyable fund.
In our ETFs, we have a predefined list of funds that we've researched that we believe
complementary to the target exposure we're looking for, and if one of those funds enters
a buy signal, it will be bought and added to the portfolio at a prescribed way.
Now, let's talk about, let's dig into that a little bit further before we go to the
kind of the cell discipline, which would be, let's say, we're going to talk about DUKQs.
Let's dig with domestic equities for the time being.
I'm sorry, domestic ETFs, since everything's funded funds are ETFs ran.
So are you picking kind of that security selection, are you picking a bench, if you will,
to apply that signal to, or are you kind of looking at a much broader universe, like,
how narrow is your scope when you're kind of looking in a general direction?
So our research refined the list of names.
So we do have a bench and a list of what, what if all the funds within our, our bench
are opportunity set that's been pre-defined, have buy signals, they will all be in a portfolio,
have exposure in the portfolio at a certain weight.
We did, we decided what funds, now that includes broad market exposures like the S&P 500
and QQQ, or the NASDAQ 100, but also small cap and mid cap exposure as well.
So we looked at all the opportunities that we could invest in during our research process
and said, okay, which ones are the most complementary to each other?
And that's how we narrowed it down to a smaller list of the individual ETFs that have specific
market exposures that we think will be additive to the diversification of the portfolio overall.
Got it.
And so then let's talk about the cell discipline.
So we've picked our bench, we've identified things that are in positive trend that we want
to own.
Right?
So on the flip side of this, when are we, when are we deciding to kind of pull the plug on those
investments and sell them and put them back on the bench?
So yeah, our cell stop discipline is just, it's a trailing stop that moves with the price
of the fund.
So just like I mentioned on the upper band, the signal for the, the cell signal for
us is the price of the fund moving below the recent high of the lower band.
And that is an automatic, unemotional cell and we will eliminate that in the portfolio.
Now, under certain conditions that may be redeployed to other funds that are still in
bi-signals for us, if certain funds are not in bi-signals, we can hold cash.
And so that, I think that's our defensive nature is to be able to hold cash during those
periods of broad market declines.
That has been, we think the, the value in our, in our strategy is to be able to, whether
the storm, so to speak, by holding cash when markets are declining broadly.
Yeah.
So that was going to be my next question and let's elaborate on this a little bit.
So get a cell signal, it doesn't necessarily, let's just say you've got a cell signal
on small caps.
Doesn't necessarily mean that that allocation is going to move directly to cash.
It can be deployed elsewhere in the market that might, you know, be a little bit less
volatile for a period of time or, or until that enters a cell zone.
So it's not, hey, one for one, we're going to allocate, making this up, 5% of the portfolio
of small caps, if it's, you know, risk off, you're not just going to bucket that to cash immediately.
Do I have that right?
Exactly.
So in that, in that example of small cap or small cap fund, hit a cell signal and we still
had a bi-signal in the S&P 500, we would reallocate that capital to the S&P 500.
So now if the S&P 500 do not have a bi-signal in, it was in a cell signal, then that's
when the portfolio can start moving to cash.
Got it.
Makes a ton of sense.
So let's dive into DUKQ.
I've been calling it duckQ.
I don't know what you guys call it short over there, but it is your domestic ETF.
So in a very high level, can you tell us what that fund is trying to accomplish?
Sure.
All of our strategies follow the same process that we just talked about, and it's applied
to different areas of the market.
In this case, domestic equities are the target exposure that we're looking for.
In that area, we have, like I said, a core exposure, then say the S&P 500 and then sort
of tertiary exposure to things like small cap, mid-cap factors, momentum.
There's a number of areas in the market we can go into that, again, our research historically
indicated would be value-add to the portfolio.
And for us, it was really about making the targeted exposure to equities.
So it can be slotted into an individual or an advisor's portfolio that generally has
an allocation in domestic equities, so it's broad-based.
And again, it's just about applying that same process, whether it's Q, we have, as you
mentioned, three other ETFs follow the same process, target different parts of the market.
This one happens to target domestic equities.
So in this particular fund, about how many securities are kind of sitting on that bench,
like what is that investable universal looks like in terms of like number of names or, you
know, if everything's in buy mode, about how many holdings can we expect in the fund
at any given time?
So it'll be about 10 to 12 names across all of our funds.
We keep it diversified, but we don't, you know, what a diversified too much.
And we think right now, it would be about 10 names.
And so when, let's say everything is risk on, right, about how are you making kind of waiting
decisions, is it going to be market cap weighted, is it weighted based off of, you know,
momentum or conviction, like how are you, how are you driving a waiting for those holdings?
Yeah.
So the weights are predetermined and what are sort of the grounding philosophy was that
we wanted core equity exposure, meaning as you think about the market cap and how that
looks, we have some, I would call them tilts relative to say a broad market, our index,
which is a more of an all cap, a broad market index, but you know, we, everything has
a prescribed weight, depending conditionally based on it, having a buy signal, right?
So, or something like a small cap ETF, you know, would have a roughly a 5% weight in the
portfolio.
So, is the fund itself, is it like purely active where you can get the signal on a Wednesday
and you're trading it on a Wednesday or do you have a kind of a weekly or monthly reconstitution
that you're kind of, you know, taking in signals over a period of time and then deploying
them?
It's a daily process.
We've based our signals on the previous day closing nav of the underlying ETFs in the
portfolio.
So, we revisit that every day and discuss, you know, it's very, again, an emotional process
where we look at, okay, is this, is this in a cell signal or not?
And if it is, obviously, it gets, it gets sold and depending on other factors, it may
get redeployed somewhere else in the portfolio or sent to cash temporarily.
Yeah.
So, without, without going, you know, again, too deep in the weeds on process, you know,
what is a typical holding period or turnover look like for a particular ETF?
Like, are you guys making shorter-term investment decisions or are you looking, you know,
are these holding periods longer in nature like where are you kind of targeting a signal
on average?
So, yeah, it depends on your definition of short-term or long-term, I suppose, but our
turnover is a typical turnover is a two times a year.
So, we would be going in and out of a fund on average.
I mean, that can vary from zero to four, but the average tends to be around two times.
You got it.
So, you know, you have a fairly active process, markets can be, you know, kind of finicky.
Can this ETF in particular, sit 100% in cash or, or short-term money markets?
Absolutely.
And that happened from time to time when the markets in complete meltdown mode, the
optionality to go to cash, I think, is what really gives us an advantage.
We don't like to be in cash, that's not a target allocation for us, but if we need to
be, we can be.
And so, the portfolio can be 100% cash if all of the funds in the opportunity set are
in sales, sales signals, then the fund will be 100% in cash.
Got it.
And I know the answer to this question, but just like, you're not, there's no, this isn't
like a pure, you're not doing any shorting, you're not buying any inverse, right?
It's either, we are either long equities or we are either in money markets.
Yeah, you call it long neutral, long cash.
I know a lot of trend followers, managed features specifically will have short exposures.
Some of the reasons we don't feel like that's necessarily a good thing for us is that the
short exposure can sort of exacerbate what we call a whipsaw risk of markets when
you get a false positive and it can changing the sign there can have some, some big
ramifications.
So that's not what we're trying to do to add to necessarily have positive performance, so
to speak, when the markets are selling off, we want to be able to just limit the losses.
And we're not really trying to limit the one standard deviation type events.
Those two and three standard deviation events that we're really focusing on and trying
to mitigate the exposure there.
And so that's how we've thought about it.
So if you're sitting down with an advisor that's already has a diversified model portfolio,
where are you advising them to kind of slot the CTFN?
Yeah, so for domestic equities, obviously, everybody with equity exposure has some exposure
to domestic equities, and it really depends on an advisor or a particular client's risk
version, right?
Some folks have greater need, greater comfort with something as strategy with more downside
protection, so this can fill the entire domestic equity bucket for a particular allocation.
Now, that's not necessarily everybody's speed, so we also say it's not zero, it doesn't
have to be 100%, but somewhere in there really, it's in a lot of times it's up to the
advisor to determine, all right, how much protection do I want to put in the portfolio?
So it's very customizable, we can think of it as being modular, right, to that specific
target allocation that are common amongst most portfolios.
So the the fund is fairly new, I believe it launched in July.
Is that right?
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
It's fairly new.
So what I know a lot of thought goes into the decision to kind of launch a fund.
So what was it for kind of you in the team over an ocean park to say, look, let's
get this thing out in an ETF wrapper, and let's go compete in the US tactical fund space.
Yes.
Oh, well, look, I think we saw what everybody else is seeing.
If you're an asset manager now, I think I've said this, that ETFs are almost table stakes,
right?
And it's still a fairly new universe, right?
It's only been since 2019 when the rule change happened and made active management more
feasible in an ETF, and we've seen a rush of products to the market, and right now,
I think there's about 1600 products out there.
We know that there are advisors that only want to use ETFs for whatever reason, obviously
tax efficiency benefits and so forth.
But there are advisors who would love to use our products, but if they're only available

So we're recognizing that reality, we said, okay, it's time to launch ETFs and give

We do think there's still plenty of room for mutual funds in the marketplace, but the

And that's where we came to the realization that we need to be able to deliver to those
advisors and clients that want ETF exposure.
Yeah, I couldn't agree more.
And so again, like being new or this fun being, this particular fun being new, you guys have

How do you go about, I think it's a very different sales process than selling solutions

I, you know, at least there are certainly differences, right?
But I think the core demand we've seen in our products for mutual funds and for the package

I've all been with meeting with financial advisors, right?
Meeting, meeting them sort of hand-to-hand combat, bringing Belly to Belly trying to educate

And we don't think that will necessarily change.
I think that the ability, we've had a lot of success in the tamp world as a fun strategist.
And I think that has to do with the fact that you give a solution to a advisor rather than

And that's great, and we still want to allow that flexibility, but for those that want

to give them an easy program to implement.
Well, I think, too, just kind of staying on the topic of, you know, ETF creation and off
this off of the solution side business, it's, you know, it gives advisors a little bit
more flexibility in a couple of areas, like, you know, if you're blending your strategies

It's going to help lower some of those model minimums to allow some entry.
The other thing, too, I think, in the solutions business, not to get too far off topic,
like that's almost erased as zero, right?
And I think if you don't have, you know, ETFs out there to kind of support that business
to allow, you know, a free model marketplace at some of these terms, you know, I think
you're going to have a hard time gathering assets, you know, probably later on down the
line, it's not happening tomorrow, but I can see a world where that starts to become
a reality.
Yeah, look, I mean, our philosophy has been, again, meeting the demand where it is.
And the reason we've had success on our mutual fund suite, and we think we'll have continued
success with ETFs is that we give advisors options to create solutions for their clients.
And the, this fund strategist model makes it so easy for them to, to make those decisions,
rather than trying to do, like I said, our 1,600 active ETFs out there.
And we, by the way, our strategies also use outside funds and additional our own funds.
So it's just a conduit to our products that we think really allows the advisor to sort
of toss the keys and say, all right, we can't necessarily figure out the right allocation
to your domestic fund, your international fund, your diversity.
So there's, it's a complicated decision, and there's an easy way to solve for that.
And I think, you know, you're just, it's just sort of a value add that I think more and

Well, James, I really appreciate your time with me today before I let you go, where can
